passage.title: The Championship Game
passage.content:
Coach Rivera called a timeout with forty-seven seconds left and the team down by two points. Everyone on the bench knew what was coming: the play would go to Jackson. It always went to Jackson.

Jackson was the best player on the team—probably the best player in the league. He could hit three-pointers with defenders hanging off him. He had a crossover that made opponents look like they were standing on ice. Every highlight reel from the season featured Jackson doing something impossible.

But as the team huddled around Coach Rivera, Marcus noticed something he'd never seen before: Jackson's hands were shaking.

'Jackson takes the final shot,' Coach said, exactly as expected. 'Marcus, you set the screen. Everyone else clears out.'

Marcus nodded, but he kept watching Jackson. The shaking hadn't stopped. Jackson's eyes were fixed on the floor, his jaw tight, his breathing shallow. Marcus had seen this look before—not on Jackson, but on his little brother Daniel before piano recitals. It was the look of someone carrying too much pressure.

The thing was, Jackson hadn't missed a game-winning shot all season. Four times now, the team had been in exactly this situation, and four times Jackson had delivered. That was the problem, Marcus realised. Jackson wasn't afraid of missing. He was afraid of what missing would mean—that the one thing everyone counted on him for might not be true anymore.

'Hey,' Marcus said quietly, leaning closer to Jackson while Coach continued diagramming the play. 'You know you don't have to make it, right?'

Jackson looked up, surprised. 'What?'

'The shot. You don't have to make it. We're still going to be a team tomorrow either way. This isn't... everything.'

Jackson stared at him for a long moment. Something in his expression shifted—the tightness in his jaw loosened just slightly.

'Thanks,' Jackson said. It wasn't much, but his hands had stopped shaking.

The buzzer sounded and the team broke the huddle. Marcus set the screen exactly as planned, and Jackson caught the ball at the three-point line with three seconds left. A defender rushed toward him, arms raised.

Jackson pump-faked, and the defender flew past. Then, instead of shooting, Jackson did something no one expected: he passed. The ball found Marcus, alone on the baseline, with no time to think.

Marcus shot. The ball arced through the air, hit the back of the rim, bounced twice, and dropped through the net as the buzzer sounded.

The crowd erupted. Teammates mobbed Marcus, shouting his name. But through the chaos, Marcus found Jackson standing at half-court, smiling.

Later, after the celebration had died down, Marcus caught up with Jackson in the parking lot.

'Why'd you pass?' Marcus asked. 'You had the shot.'

Jackson shrugged. 'You told me I didn't have to make it. I figured that meant I didn't have to take it either.' He paused. 'Besides, you were more open than I was. It was the right play.'

Marcus laughed. 'Since when do you make the right play?'

'Since someone reminded me it's not everything,' Jackson said.

questions.stem: Marcus's primary motivation for speaking to Jackson during the timeout is that he:

mcqOptions.text: Wants Jackson to pass him the ball instead
mcqOptions.feedback: Marcus never suggests he wants the ball. His words ('You don't have to make it') are about relieving pressure, not about getting the shot himself.

mcqOptions.text: Thinks the play should go to someone else
mcqOptions.feedback: Marcus never questions the play call. He accepts his role ('Marcus nodded') and speaks to Jackson privately about pressure, not about changing the strategy.

mcqOptions.text: Is angry that Jackson gets all the attention
mcqOptions.feedback: There's no indication of jealousy or anger. Marcus's words are supportive and kind—he's trying to help Jackson, not express resentment.

mcqOptions.text: Recognises Jackson is struggling under pressure and wants to help
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Marcus notices Jackson's shaking hands and connects it to 'the look of someone carrying too much pressure.' His quiet words are an attempt to relieve that pressure.

hints.content: What does Marcus observe about Jackson that others might miss?
What does Marcus compare Jackson's look to? What does that comparison tell us?
He sees 'someone carrying too much pressure'—he speaks up to help relieve it.

questions.stem: According to Marcus's insight, Jackson's fear before the shot comes from:

mcqOptions.text: Lack of confidence in his shooting ability
mcqOptions.feedback: The TEXT states: 'Jackson wasn't afraid of missing.' He HAS confidence in his ability. The fear is about what missing would MEAN, not about whether he CAN make it.

mcqOptions.text: Physical fatigue from playing the entire game
mcqOptions.feedback: There's no mention of tiredness. Marcus explicitly identifies this as PRESSURE, not exhaustion. Jackson's hands shake from anxiety, not physical fatigue.

mcqOptions.text: Worry that missing would change how people see his identity
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Marcus realises Jackson fears 'what missing would mean—that the one thing everyone counted on him for might not be true anymore.' It's about identity, not just one miss.

mcqOptions.text: Concern that his teammates will be angry with him
mcqOptions.feedback: The fear isn't about teammates' anger. It's about Jackson's IDENTITY—being the person who always makes the shot. The fear is about who he is, not others' reactions.

textEvidence.quoteHint: afraid of what missing would mean

nswSelectiveReading.questionFunction: Distinguish surface fear from deeper motivation

hints.content: What does Marcus say Jackson is NOT afraid of?
What does Marcus say Jackson IS actually afraid of?
'Afraid of what missing would mean'—losing his identity as the reliable star.

questions.stem: Marcus's words 'We're still going to be a team tomorrow either way' are designed to:

mcqOptions.text: Remind Jackson that there will be more games next season
mcqOptions.feedback: Marcus isn't talking about future games—he's talking about TOMORROW, about the team's relationships continuing regardless of tonight's result.

mcqOptions.text: Suggest that the game does not matter
mcqOptions.feedback: Marcus doesn't say the game doesn't matter—he says 'This isn't everything.' There's a difference between important and EVERYTHING. He's putting it in perspective, not dismissing it.

mcqOptions.text: Warn Jackson that losing might affect the team
mcqOptions.feedback: This is the OPPOSITE of Marcus's message. He's saying the team bond WON'T be affected—'still going to be a team'—not that it will.

mcqOptions.text: Separate Jackson's worth from the outcome of one shot
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Marcus is telling Jackson that team relationships and Jackson's value aren't dependent on making this shot. He's separating Jackson's worth from one performance.

textEvidence.quoteHint: still going to be a team tomorrow

hints.content: What was Jackson worried about (from Marcus's insight)?
How do Marcus's words address that specific worry?
Jackson fears losing his identity; Marcus says 'team tomorrow'—worth isn't tied to outcome.

questions.stem: Jackson's decision to pass instead of shoot is motivated by:

mcqOptions.text: Desire to prove Marcus's words wrong
mcqOptions.feedback: Jackson's explanation ('you were more open than I was') shows he's AGREEING with Marcus's philosophy, not trying to prove him wrong.

mcqOptions.text: Wanting Marcus to experience success for once
mcqOptions.feedback: While Marcus does succeed, Jackson explains his reason: 'It was the right play.' The decision was about basketball strategy, not about giving Marcus a moment.

mcqOptions.text: Freedom from the need to be the one who always scores
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Marcus freed Jackson from the pressure of having to make the shot. This freedom allowed Jackson to see and make 'the right play'—passing to the open player.

mcqOptions.text: Fear that he would miss the shot
mcqOptions.feedback: Jackson's hands stopped shaking after Marcus's words—the fear was addressed. The pass wasn't about fear; it was about being free to make the best play.

textEvidence.quoteHint: didn't have to take it either

nswSelectiveReading.questionFunction: Connect earlier dialogue to later action

hints.content: What did Marcus tell Jackson he didn't have to do?
How does Jackson extend Marcus's message in his explanation?
'Didn't have to make it' became 'didn't have to take it'—freedom to choose the best play.

questions.stem: Jackson's explanation that 'you were more open than I was' reveals that his true motivation was:

mcqOptions.text: Showing that he does not care about his statistics
mcqOptions.feedback: The pass wasn't about making a statement about statistics—it was about making 'the right play.' Jackson is explaining basketball logic, not rejecting stats.

mcqOptions.text: Making the best decision for the team rather than for himself
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Jackson could have taken the shot for personal glory but chose the objectively better play. The pass was about team success, not individual heroics.

mcqOptions.text: Hoping the defender would look foolish
mcqOptions.feedback: While Jackson does fake out the defender, his explanation focuses entirely on Marcus being open—not on embarrassing anyone.

mcqOptions.text: Testing whether Marcus could handle pressure
mcqOptions.feedback: Jackson didn't have time to test anything—there were three seconds left. The decision was immediate and strategic, not an experiment.

nswSelectiveReading.questionFunction: Understand character growth through action explanation

hints.content: What reason does Jackson give for passing?
Is 'you were more open' about Jackson or about winning?
'More open' = best chance to score = team success over personal glory.

questions.stem: Jackson's final statement—'Since someone reminded me it's not everything'—suggests his overall change in motivation from:

mcqOptions.text: Carrying the burden of always performing to playing freely as part of a team
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Before, Jackson felt he HAD to deliver (burden). After Marcus's words, he could play without that pressure—making the right play freely rather than feeling forced to be the hero.

mcqOptions.text: Being selfish to being generous with his teammates
mcqOptions.feedback: The passage doesn't portray Jackson as selfish before. Taking shots when you're the best player isn't selfish—it's strategic. The change is about PRESSURE, not selfishness.

mcqOptions.text: Disliking Marcus to respecting him
mcqOptions.feedback: There's no indication Jackson ever disliked Marcus. The change isn't about their relationship—it's about Jackson's relationship with PRESSURE.

mcqOptions.text: Wanting to win to not caring about the outcome
mcqOptions.feedback: Jackson still wanted to win—he made 'the right play' to maximise chances. He didn't stop caring; he stopped feeling the outcome defined him.

hints.content: What was Jackson like at the beginning (shaking hands, tight jaw)?
What did Jackson feel he HAD to do before? What could he CHOOSE to do after?
Before: burden of always delivering. After: freedom to make the right play.
